- Specific vs general deterrence: Specific deterrence is whether a punishment deters the individual criminal from reoffending in the future. General deterrence is whether the punishment deters the general public from committing crimes. - Threshold effects: There may be certain "thresholds" of punishment severity that have a disproportionate deterrent effect. For example, the jump from no punishment to a minor punishment may deter a lot of crime, but further increases in severity may have diminishing returns. This could explain why life imprisonment is as effective as the death penalty in many cases.

Ultimately, the effectiveness of a punishment depends on the interaction of all these complex factors, not just the severity alone.
